data.headline: Weekend Brief: US equity futures edge higher after Supreme Court tariff ruling as traders brace for renewed trade-war fears and a data-heavy week ahead
bullets: S&P 500 gained 0.7% Friday and 1.1% for the week, while Nasdaq rose 0.9% and 1.9% led by Meta, Nvidia, and Amazon on AI spending optimism
Supreme Court rejected Trump’s IEEPA tariffs, but his pivot to a 15% global tariff under Section 122 stoked trade-war and deficit concerns
Existing Section 232/301 tariffs remain, clouding outlook for trade-sensitive sectors like consumer discretionary, tech, semis, autos, and exporters
Asian markets traded mixed to lower on US-Iran tensions and tariff confusion, with Hang Seng down 1.1%
European markets ended the week modestly higher, supported by rare-earth supply deals and energy gains from Iran-linked oil price climb
Private-credit jitters pressured Blue Owl, Ares, and Blackstone, while major banks were spared despite renewed scrutiny after JPMorgan’s Trump account admission
Bitcoin’s volatility and 'identity crisis' weighed on COIN and MSTR shares
Traders face a lighter Monday calendar but a data-heavy week, including Fed Governor Waller’s speech, S&P Global PMIs, factory orders, and Nvidia’s key earnings report
Prediction markets now price a 58% chance of an S&P 500 correction in 2026 amid elevated volatility
